item.description:
“Luke, Han and Leia need to get back to the Millennium Falcon in the Death Star’s Docking Bay. But Vader and his minions are in hot pursuit.”

The game is played on the map from the Escape From the Death Star miniature game, or the players may design a custom map. The object of the game is to destroy all of your opponent’s characters. Each player controls three characters. The Rebel player plays Luke Skywalker, Princess Leia, and Han Solo. The Empire player plays Darth Vader, an anonymous Stormtrooper, and (from the Episode III cutting room floor?) Boba Fett.
Each character has a deck of cards containing a specific number of Power, Toughness, and Force cards in allocations intended to represent the relative abilities of the characters. These cards are used to resolve combat. Movement of the characters is determined by drawing Area cards.

A card game based on the rise of ancient civilizations. The cards represent Advancements, Cities, Leaders, Wonders, and Events. The players build Cities and Wonders, establish trade (to gain Advancements held by opponents), and start wars. The possibility of catastrophic events always looms in the background. The object of the game is to have the most Victory Points after the deck has been gone through twice.

“In this game you play a Lensman Ranger with his intergalactic assault scout ship. You must use your Lensman Powers to undermine enemy bases while battling any Morad ships that you encounter . . . When you have successfully infiltrated and brought down all four Morad quadrant bases in the Second Galaxy, you win.”

This solitaire game is played by randomly selecting cards from a deck containing a variety of Morad ships (frigates, destroyers, and cruisers) and four “Quadrent Base” cards. You must defeat each ship until you have encountered and successfully infiltrated all four bases. Each ship is rated for power, hull strength, number of weapons/attacks, and weapon strength.

“Players are modern-day, rich, athletic, leisure-minded adventurers.”

The players choose one of three traits for their adventurer: “World Class Athlete”, “Filthy Rich”, or “No Responsibilities.” The players collect and play resource cards allowing them to complete adventures such as “Running of the Bulls”, “Sahara Marathon”, “Ski the South Pole”, and “Suborbital Space Flight.”

The game ends when there are no Adventure cards left, at which point the player with the highest Victory Point total wins.

A game of archaeological adventuring set in the 1930’s and 1940’s. Save the damsel, defeat the villain, and recover the ancient artifact before your adversaries can!

The players choose their adventurer type from a variety of professions, such as Archaeologist, Daredevil Pilot, Occult Expert, Private Investigator, or Soldier of Fortune. Each profession confers a special benefit.

Through drawing and playing cards, the players conduct research, travel to exotic locations, acquire weapons and other useful items, and attempt to escape dangerous encounters.

To win the game, be the first player to visit five locations, the last of which must be an Ancient location, which represents the successful recovery of the ancient relic.

A fantasy adventure boardgame based on the Talislanta role-playing game. The game is played on a randomly constructed map made out of an 11x11 array of map tiles. Each player randomly chooses a character from a deck of around forty character cards. The players journey around the map, facing deadly encounters, and attempt to complete adventures (tests of strength). If a player’s character is killed, a new character is drawn and the player continues the game with that character. The object of the game is to be the first player to successfully complete five adventures.

link.value: From RPG books to board games

item.description: A card game for two or more players based on the book “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” by Lewis Carroll. The game is played using a deck containing Character Cards, Location Cards, Action Cards, and Modifier Cards. The object of the game is to wake up the opposing players by increasing their Insanity Totals. In addition to the standard set of cards, the rules provide a second set of cards based on “Through the Looking Glass.”

From the deigner :
“Simulation of the North Africa campaign of WWII. 
Card game for two players.
One player is the Germans (& Italians), the other player is the Commonwealth (British & Allies).”

Each game turn consists of three phases. In the Logistics Phase, the players draw a hand of cards (the number drawn by each player varies from six to eight depending on the stage of the war). In the Strategy Phase, the players may discard up to three cards and draw replacements. In the Battle Phase, the players reveal their hands and the player with the highest Force point total wins the hand and takes a Terrain Token from the loser.

Each player starts the game with three Terrain Tokens. The game ends when one player controls all six Terrain Tokens.

Subtitel: Een bloedfanatiek spel

A race game were you roll the dice, move and have to answer questions about blood in 4 categories.

Sanquin is a Blood Supply foundation http://www.sanquin.nl/sanquin-eng/sqn_home_eng.nsf

“A two-player card game of modern tank combat. Each player starts the game with 16 AFV (Armored Fighting Vehicle) Tokens. Reduce your opponent to 0 AFV tokens.”

Each player starts with a hand of ten cards drawn from a common deck. The card types include Offensive Attack, Defensive Attack, Units, Weapons, Movement, Obstacle, Protection, Leadership, Morale, and Reconnaissance. Each turn has 8 phases: Deploy Phase, Leadership Phase, Reconnaissance Phase, Defensive Phase, Defensive Movement Phase, Offensive Phase, Offensive Movement Phase, and Redeploy Phase.

In order to win the game, a player must play cards to mount successful attacks which result in the opponent's loss of AFV tokens.

“Two Player Board & Card Game of Modern Tank Combat. Victory: Destroy all enemy Armored Fighting Vehicle Units. Units: Each player starts the game with 8 AFV (Armored Fighting Vehicle) Units. Use Miniatures, counters, or tokens to represent AFV’s. Each Unit represents a combined arms squadron.”

The play of the cards is central to the game, as the cards control when the AFV's can move, attack, and defend.

“A card game for 2 to 4 players, or more. Each player controls a country during the First Industrial Revolution. Players try to develop their economies as quickly as possible.” The game is played with two sets of cards, an Industry Deck and an Event Deck.

There are seven categories of “Resources” that are tracked for each country: Food, Population (Skilled and Unskilled Labor), Fossil Fuels, Steel (Production Capacity), Transportation, Guns, and Luxury Goods (Peacetime Consumption). Each country begins with an equal amount of resources.

“The first player to have a combined score of 100+ in Guns and Luxury Goods wins. If more than 1 person gets 100+ on the same turn, the Player with the higher score wins. If it is still tied, use Transportation, and then Population, as tie-breakers.”

“Greek Heroes undertake adventures of Mythic proportions. Players accumulate Heroes, City States, Relics, and great Victories over legendary monsters with the aid of the Gods. To play you will have to make your own cards. There are 129 cards in the deck.”

The object of the game is to accumulate the most Victory Points. Victory Points are acquired by controlling Heroes and City States, owning Relics, winning Wars, holding Blessing cards, and successfully completing Challenges.

A bidding card game in which the players control airlines. The object is to have the most money at the end of the game.

The game is played using a custom deck consisting of 110 cards of three different types: Planes, Landing Rights, and Events. Landing Rights cards are also called Terminals. Also required for play are a ten-sided die and a paper and pen to record profits (or play money may be used to represent profits instead).

Each player starts the game with 50 million dollars, one Boeing 737 or one McDonnell Douglas DC-9, and landing rights to two Minor Airports. The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck.

A game of modern jet fighter dogfighting for two players. Each player starts with two jets: a leader and a wingman. You win the game by shooting your opponent’s planes out of the air.

The game uses a custom deck of over 150 cards which regulate movement and combat. The game may be played on a chess board or any other 8x8 grid. Also required for play are six-sided dice, miniature airplanes that fit within the squares of the board, and counters to keep track of missiles and damage.

“Two player card game simulating modern Jet Fighter Air Combat. Objective: Kill all of your opponent’s planes. Setup: In the standard game each side has 2 planes: A flight leader and his wingman. For a quick game play one-on-one. A dogfight involving many planes is referred to as a Furball. Use coins or dice to keep track of planes.”

The game is played using a deck of seven different types of cards: Pilot, Initiative, Tactics (Team), Maneuver, Attack, Defense, and Kill. The players attempt to play a superior number of Maneuver and Attack cards, and ultimately score a kill with a Kill card.

“Players control fanciful Victorian Airships used to complete various Missions around the Globe. Background: The year is 1850 and Airships rule the Skies! Victory: The first player to accumulate 20 Victory Points is the winner.” Victory Points are lost or gained based on how successfully Missions are completed.

Each player controls an Airship which has six basic traits: Military, Exploration, Diplomacy, Transportation, Rescue, and Speed. Attachment and Crew cards help improve various traits. Each airship starts with five randomly drawn Crew cards and Attachment cards. The Crew cards represent exceptional people aboard the Airship. The Attachment cards represent Weapons, Tools, Rooms, and Equipment built into the Airship.

Components: Three decks of cards (Mission Deck, Crew Deck, and Attachment Deck) and two ten-sided dice.

"Feed me!" the little yellow seal begs the zoo keeper.
"No, feed me first – I’m much more hungry!" the green seal whines.
And at once all four seals open their mouth and start howling. Desperately the zoo keeper looks from one seal to the other – which one should he feed first? A smart idea occurs to him; "Lets play a game together.Whoever wins, gets a fish!"
"Hurray, playing games is fun!" the seals cheer and flap their flippers. Impatiently they wait for the game to start.

Game 1. Feeding the Seals
Roll the die. If a colored seal appears either open or close it's mouth (on the game board). If a fish appears, and the corresponding seal's mouth is open, feed it. The game ends as soon as a player has fed a seal with their last fish.

Game 2. No, no – I Don’t Like Fish!
This is a variant of Go Fish, but with the fish tiles and the open mouthed seals on the board.

Game 3. I want fish!
As in Game #1 but each players has a secret seal (color) identity. When feeding a seal, if your color's mouth is closed, you must feed someone else's seal. The player whose seal has eaten the most fish wins.

Suspect Behavior is a free party game by Tim Denee. One player is the inspector and the others are the suspects. Each suspect wrights down who he or she thinks did it and then the investigator questions each suspect until he or she knows who did it.

In this game, it is not the one who receives the most cards who will win, but the one who organizes his cards in the best way so that he/she can play them both tactically and cleverly. Before every turn, the playing conditions for that hand - esp. regarding the trump - is decided by all players.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A tactical battle game for up to four players, using tiles to form the gameboard, and coins ("armies") and pawns ("commanders") as playing pieces. Dice are used to determine how far pieces can move, while the coin values determine the outcome of the one-on-one battles that take place in the game. The objective of the game is to move your Commander onto another player’s Home Base tile.

Rules can be found on the piecepack wiki.

Game System

 Piecepack Game System

Each player takes the part of an archaeologist discovering the secrets of one of the great pyramids and its sacred sarcophagus, hoping to gain the most fame by the end of the expedition.

Sarcophagus is played with a piecepack, the tiles are laid in a pyramid shape, with 3 doubled up at the bottom, as players put their influence markers (coins) on the tiles, more of the pyramid is revealed and they have new areas to compete over. Unless you have a god tile to protect you, watch out for the those traps!

Rules are available on the piecepack wiki.

Game System

 Piecepack Game System

Bathtub rubber ducky racing has long been a popular sport. Every year rubber duckies from all walks of life train in bathtubs, spas and small ponds around the world to prepare for the annual Kenducky Derby, the premier bathtub ducky race.

duck! duck! GO! comes with 6 REAL rubber duckies, and a rubber bird dog. There are over 100 duckies in the set - which ones will YOU get?

Each round, choose a movement card from your hand. When it is your turn, race your ducky according to the directions on the card.

Be the first ducky to touch all the buoys and get back to the finish drain to win!

NOTE: The current, in-print edition plays up to four, and comes with four ducks in the box. The first edition played up to six, and came with the same.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Alien races with varying powers compete to control twenty worlds. The Alien Race which establishes control over all of the Worlds wins the game.

The card deck used in the game includes three types of cards: Force cards, Race cards, and Event cards. Each player also requires a uniquely colored set of fifty or more Control markers. The game may be played on any hex map with the twenty World markers distributed as the players see fit.

Your quest for galactic conquest starts from the home world of your choice. In addition, you begin the game with three Race cards that define abilities, traits and powers that your alien race will possess throughout the game.

A card game pitting one player’s Colonial Marines versus the other player’s Aliens.

Each player has a deck of 36 cards equally divided into three suits (Combatants, Weapons, and Tactics). Players attempt to build hands with the greatest combat value. When battles are lost, the cards are discarded to a Casualty Pile.

The game ends when all of a player’s cards are in the Casualty Pile, at which point the other player wins the game.

A card game based on the Sid Meier computer game of the same name.

The game is played with a custom card deck composed of the following types of cards: Events, Technologies, Structures, Special Projects, Landmarks, Proposals, and Social Engineering. Tokens and markers are used to keep track of Bases (cities), Units (military forces), and Credits (income).

Six social factors, also referred to as scores, are tracked for each player’s Faction: Population, Economics, Research, Military, Ecology, and Espionage. These factors are used to determine victory.

There are four types of victory defined in the game: Diplomatic, Economic, Conquest, and Transcendence. The first player to achieve any one of these victory conditions wins the game.

A card game set in the world of Amber as described in the series of novels by Roger Zelazny. This game depicts nine Princes fighting to control Amber sometime after the disappearance of King Oberon. The game is won by controlling Amber for five consecutive turns, or controlling Amber and capturing or killing all Princes controlled by opposing players.

A simple hunting themed card game. The object of the game is to be the first player to make a kill. To do so, a player must acquire two Technique cards and one each of the Weapon, Habitat, Prey, and Spoiler cards.

“Two player Card game of the American Revolution. One player is the Americans, the other is the British."

"Players share a common deck. The card list has 120+ cards."

"The game is played in 7 Strategic turns corresponding to the 7 years of the war: 1775, 1776, 1777, 1778, 1779, 1780, 1781."

"Victory: The winner is the first player to win 3 turns in a row, or if this does not occur, the player to win turn 1781. (It’s not how many battles you won, it’s who won the last battle.)”

A fantasy themed multi-player Mastermind style deduction game.

"A (not really) fantasy game of deduction for 3-5 players. Five spirits are captured in five amulets. The wizards try to find out their correct placements on the altar to cast the freeing spell. Succeeding means honour, failure means
eternal doom."

Designer's note: "This game, years old and deriving from boring school times, is nothing else but a master mind clone, but a funky multi-player one. Experienced players should not need more than 5-6 questions. This is not really a party game, since all players stare at their notes and beg each active player for a thinking break :) - give it a try."

“Ancients Wargame with emphasis on Command & Control. Victory: You win if you rout the opposing General.”

Played on a square grid with terrain arranged as desired by the players. The game includes a detailed scenario generation system which allows for randomly determined army quality and composition, and leaders of varying ability (including attributes for “legendary generals.”) The rules also describe special characteristics and/or special units for the Egyptians, Mongols, Greeks, Athenians, Spartans, Persians, Romans, Carthaginians, and Celts.

Each player is a general fielding an ancient army represented by the cards in their respective decks. The game includes a deck of 100 cards, composed of 60 Tactics cards and 40 Unit cards. Each player is dealt 50 cards to start the game. The object is to destroy your opponent’s army by causing him to run out of cards. A player loses once he has no more cards left in his deck or reserve pile.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
“Battle between two Ancient Armies. Bronze Age/Age of the Chariot. Each figure represents a group of 500 men. Victory: You win if you destroy the opposing General or Camp.”

Chits or miniatures are used to represent the combat units. The units come in six types: Heavy Infantry, Light Infantry, Heavy Cavalry, Light Cavalry, General, and Camp.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid (chessboard) representing the battlefield. Each player starts with one unit on each square of his back two rows. Units may not stack.
 There are four custom card decks used in the game: the Infantry Deck, Cavalry Deck, Shock Deck, and Missile Deck. The cards are used to initiate movement and combat, and to defend against attacks.

“Battle between ancient armies. Each figure represents a general, camp or unit of troops. Victory: You win if you destroy your opponent’s General or 8 of his units. A Camp counts as 2 units.”

Chits or miniatures are used to represent the combat units. The game is played on an 8x8 grid (or chessboard) to represent a small battlefield. Each army consists of a General, a Camp, and eleven other units. Each player places his units on his back two rows. Units may not stack. The players draw from a deck of cards and use their hand of cards to initiate movement and combat, and to defend against attacks.

The players control rival ant colonies. To win the game you must destroy all rival opposing colonies. The game is played on an 8x8 grid, such as a chess board, that represents the backyard of a suburban house. Terrain is randomly placed and consists of sweet spots (food), concrete slabs, dry spots, and covered spots. Each player starts with a colony of ten ants in a corner of the board. A deck of cards is used to resolve combat. Card play also permits a colony to nest to generate more ant units.

“Solo Card Game System simulating the Arab Israeli Wars 1948+. Currently only cards set for the Israeli War of Independence is available. The player takes the role of the Israelis. Arab deployments are automatic.”

The game is played on three Fronts: the Northern Frontier (Galilee), Central Frontier (Jerusalem), and Southern front (Negev). Each Front is represented by six Territory Tokens, all of which are under the control of the Israelis (the solo player) at the start of the game. If the Arabs are able to acquire control all six tokens on any one Front, you suffer a Complete Loss. If you win all battles on all three Fronts for two turns in a row, you achieve a Decisive Victory. If the Arabs run out of unit cards, you achieve an Attrition Victory.

The Unit cards are intended to represent Arab and Israeli forces involved in the 1948 hostilities. Units are drawn and played to the Fronts - Arab units to designated Fronts and Israeli cards as desired by the player. Each turn one card is drawn from the Event deck. The Event card confers benefits to one side or the other.

A simple boardgame of high adventure in the mysterious lands of Arabia. The game is played on a square track with 10 spaces per side (for a total of 36 spaces) with the corners designated as Baghdad, Mecca, Medina, and the Silk Road. All other spaces are empty and large enough to hold one of the Adventure Cards. The Adventure Deck and discard pile sit in the center of the board.

Players travel around the board acquiring treasures (and trying to steal them from other players). The players also face challenges. If a player fails a challenge, the Challenge Card is placed on the space the player occupies and any player landing on the card must confront the challenge.

The game ends when a player is required to draw a card but there are no cards left in the Adventure Deck. Victory is determined based on the acquisition of Fortune, Fame, and Faith points.

A strategic scale fantasy wargame depicting the struggle between Mages (Archmagi), who use spells, heroes, monsters, armies, and artifacts to destroy each other and conquer the world.

The game is played on a hex map randomly created during the course of the game, or created using an online random map generator. The players start at the opposite ends of the mapsheet with their randomly selected Archmagi, and a small assortment of units and spells. The goal is to destroy all opposing Archmagi units.

At start, all non-player Archmagi chits, Spell chits, Banner chits, Artifact chits, and Unit chits are set aside to be recruited by the players in the course of the game. Units may only be recruited from the territory in which they originate, e.g. Dwarves in the mountains, Elves in the forest, Trolls in the swamp, etc. The players obtain Artifacts (magic weapons/items) by turning in two reserve Units. Each player receives three randomly selected spells every turn, but a player may only hold a total of seven spells at a time.

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A Gin Rummy influenced card game based on the philosophies and theories of the famous architect Paolo Soleri.

The custom deck is composed of five types of cards: Arcology, Structure, Energy, Theory, and Philosophy. The objective of the game is to be the first to build three Arcologies.

A player builds an Arcology by playing a meld of one Arcology card and two of each other type of card. Certain cards count as two cards when building certain Arcologies.

“A Game of Fantasy Gladiatorial Combat for 2-6 players. The players take the roles of owners of a team of warriors who do battle in The Arena, a circle of battle, blood and death. Their teams consist of brave Humans, the graceful, catlike Ptemet, the insectoid Keet’Norn, the brutish Orghar, and the deadly Vashail, who battle for glory, money and at their master’s whim. Life is cheap, death is easy, but glory is eternal!”

The players are allocated funds to set up their gladiatorial team. Warriors, weapons and armor must be purchased. In addition, there are campaign rules to chart a team’s progress from one game to the next.

This game is played on a Backgammon board using opposing sets of 15 green army men and 15 tan army men (or any other contrasting colors available). The game also requires two six-sided dice.

The types army men are rated based on the weapon carried (which establishes attack range) and stance (which sets the maximum movement and saving throw values). Units that are standing or running can move faster but are more vulnerable, while units that are prone or kneeling can’t move as fast but are less vulnerable.

When one of your men is hit, it is removed from the game. If the piece designated as your Sergeant is removed from the game, then your remaining men must either dig-in or charge on every turn. The winner is the first player to move a man off the opponent’s side of the Backgammon board.

It’s good versus “med”-evil in this game of combat based on the Evil Dead film Army of Darkness.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Each player controls 18 creatures, represented by miniatures or counters, which are based on characters from the film (such as Ash, Evil Ash, Archers, and Deadite Warriors.) The good guys also have the Deathcoaster car at their disposal.

The object of the game is to eliminate all of the opposing units. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

A tactical combat rules system for pitting plastic army men against plastic fantasy figures, such as those found in Heroquest (hence the "Quest" name of this game.) The units are rated for hit points, movement allowance, attack range, and hit probability. The player who eliminates all of the opposing pieces wins the game.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A game for two players; one being the North(Blue) and the other being the South(Gray). Game is played in alternating Game Turns, each composed of a series of sequential phases.

Part of the One Page War Series

Tula resembles solitaire & Shanghai. Players use a Piecepack set for the tiles. The tiles are setup in a temple arrangement and can be removed from the temple if they match the stack in either suit or value.

A two-player game in the spirit of Backgammon. The game is played on a ring of twelve round spaces numbered one to twelve. Two white six-sided dice and a colored six-sided die are required for play. Each player requires a different colored set of twelve tokens that are capable of being stacked. The game provides several victory conditions: capture all of your opponent’s tokens, occupy any nine spaces, occupy any five spaces in a row, or occupy a defined set of four spaces (12-1-2-3, or 3-4-5-6, or 6-7-8-9, or 9-10-11-12.)

A game based on the classic action-strategy computer game of the same name. The game is played on an 8×8 grid (such as a chess board.) Victory is achieved by occupying all four corner squares or by eliminating all enemy creatures.

Each player has a unique set of eight fighting creatures, all of which are rated for hits, movement, and attack. The Light forces consist of the Wizard, Unicorn, Archer, Golem, Valkyrie, Djinni, Phoenix, and Knight. The Dark forces are the Sorceress, Basilisk, Manticore, Troll, Shapeshifter, Dragon, Banshee, and Goblin.

Card play is central to the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and the cards permit units to move, attack, and cast spells.

A card game based on the classic Jules Verne adventure tale of the same name. The players compete to be the first to travel forty Units of Distance, with a major victory being scored if a player finishes the trip in ten turns (the equivalent of eighty days in game time). The players travel by playing cards representing modes of transportation. The euphemistically named Adventure cards, representing various calamities, may be played on opposing players to impede their progress.

“Original Victorian Themed version of the WarpQuest Gaming System. Each player controls a party of adventuring archaeologists and treasure hunters trying to be the first to get some, relic, artifact, or treasure and bring it back.”

The game is played on a single winding path of connected squares, generally 30 spaces long. The action is driven by cards drawn from the scenario specific deck. The mapboard path and card deck are subdivided to represent different stages of the adventure. Typically one deck is used for the first fifteen spaces on the path -- the second deck is used for the last fifteen spaces on the path.

The scenarios available for Artifact include: Depths of the Earth (first travel through the Earth’s crust, then adventure in the Lost World of dinosaurs), Mummys Tomb (first travel down the Nile, then explore the tomb searching for the treasure of the pharaoh), Lost Continent of Atlantis (travel deep below the sea by submarine, then explore the lost continent in diving suits searching for the Pearl Trident), and The Shadow of a Dark God (a Cthulhu style scenario where the players first investigate a friend’s death, then search a cult temple).

“Players take the roles of the first foundation (psychohistorians) and the second foundation (mentalists). They compete for control of the future second galactic empire. Victory: The player who first wins the Second Galactic Empire Phase wins.”

The game is played using a shared custom deck of cards, although certain cards are only usable by one side or the other. The cards represent personalities, objects, and locations from Asimov’s Foundation series.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. The center four spaces represent a Gaul Village where the players start. The remaining sixty spaces are randomly filled with map tiles representing terrain and objects. The players earn Victory Points by bringing Mistletoe, Menhir, and Boar Tiles back to the Village. Landing on a Roman Cohort also scores Victory Points.

A tabletop “Space Opera Miniature Game” based on the designer’s story of the same name.

“It is now the dawn of the five hundredth millennium since the birth of Christ. The Empire of Man has reached out into the intergalactic depths of space, and a lost son has been found…unfortunately. The great Quantumliners of the Scouting Guild has encountered an artificial species completely inimical to humanity. Each alien robot is directly controlled by a single artificial intelligence known as Ladek! The twisted, disembodied mind of the former human scientist now lords over these automaton artifacts of a long extinct race. They have invaded every galaxy controlled by man’s glorious Imperium, and have begun a systematic extermination of every human life it encounters. While the Imperial Navy and Marine Corp defends the home galaxies against the attacks of these monsters, it falls to the Scouting Guild to hunt out and destroy Ladek units along the Imperium’s frontier worlds.”

“One player plays the Human Imperial Scouts and the other plays the Ladek Marine Robots. Forces are ‘purchased’ by means of points. Both sides must decide how many points they should begin with. I highly suggest beginning a campaign (a series of wargames between the same player(s)) with fifty points for each side.” The object of the game is to destroy all the opposing units.

A game of empire building and conquest in outer space. Each player starts with a home system and ten random units. The players explore space searching for new planets, establish diplomatic relations with inhabited planets, and build colonies to bring in revenue. Revenue is required to maintain fleets and train new leaders. As the empires of the players become more technologically advanced, they gain access to more sophisticated spacecraft and installations.

“Two player Card game simulating trench warfare in WWI. Objective: Reduce your opponent to 0 troops, or 
capture all six territory markers.” The game is web published, but was previously printed in an issue of the SGS magazine Strategist.

The players begin the game with a battalion of 100 squads, three territory markers, and no cards. The players alternate completing a sequence of five phases: Logistics (draw one card), Artillery Barrage (eliminate a random number of enemy squads), Charge Orders (the player may choose to charge, or such orders may be received), Defender Fire Phase, and Trench Fighting Phase. Certain cards may be played to give bonuses in some phases.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: A shagadelic card game based on the Austin Powers movies. The game is played with two decks containing 50 cards each, a Groovy deck for the International Man of Mystery and an Evil Deck for Doctor Evil. There are five card types in each deck. In the Groovy Deck, these are: Austin Power, Special Agent, Catch Phrases, and Spy Stuff. In the Evil Deck, the card types are: Doctor Evil, Hench Men, Evil Equipment, Diabolical Schemes, and One Liners. The first player to accumulate 10 or more Mojo Points wins.

“Abstract simulation of the Battle of the Bulge (Ardennes). Each figure (unit) represents a division. One player is the Germans, the other is the Allies (Americans & British). Time Table: Each turn is one day starting December 16, 1944. Allies may make Air Attacks starting Dec 26. Victory: The Germans win if they can occupy Bastogne, St. Vith, Liege, Namur, and Dinant. The Americans win if the Destroy all German Divisions or by January 16.”

The game is played on a 14x14 grid and utilizes a deck of approximately seventy cards. Movement and Attack cards must be played in order for your units to move or attack. The number 1 or 2 appears on each of these cards, establishing the distance of the movement or range for the attack. There are also cards which can be played to negate Movement and Attack cards.

A card game based on the character of Avatar, The Last Airbender.

“Each player is trying to help the Avatar complete Quests on their own turn and preventing their opponents from completing quests on their turns. Victory: The Player with the most Quest Points when the game ends is the winner. Game End: The game ends the turn after there are no cards left in the deck. Quest Points: Each card in your Victory Pile is worth 1 Quest Point.”

A game based on the Avengers superheroes from the Marvel Universe. The game is played using three custom decks which are shared by both players: the Foe Deck, Plot Deck, and Hero Deck. The players attempt to defeat Foes by playing Hero cards having a higher total value than the Foe Meld, a total of the values of the current Foe card and three Plot cards. The first player to defeat five Foes is the winner.

“Abstract skirmish level combat with Star Trek theme. Each figure represents a single man (or alien). Victory: You win if you kill all opposing men.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Each player starts with a team of eight men. Miniatures or counters, which are marked by race and officer type, are used to represent the combatants. Statistics are given for four types of teams: Federation, Klingon, Romulan, and Borg. Each player chooses one type of team at the start of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

“Battle between Aztecs & Conquistadors. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Leader.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters may be used to represent the combatants. The Aztec force consists of a War Leader, two Jaguar Knights, two Eagle Knights, and 19 Warriors. The Conquistador force consists of a Captain, two Cannons, four Horsemen, and eight Soldiers. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

A card game inspired by the events and characters of the movie Barbarella.

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are six suits in the deck, each with nine cards. The suites are Barbarella, Allies, Foes, Places, Events, and Things. The players score points by playing six-card combos. Scoring is as follows: one point for three pairs, two points for two three-of-a-kinds, three points for a flush, and four points for a straight which includes one card from each of the six suits. The first player to reach ten points wins the game.

“Battle between Rebels & Imperial troops on the Icy World of Hoth. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe. Each figure represents a hero, vehicle or unit of troops. Victory: The Rebels win if they destroy all the AT-AT Walkers. The Empire wins if they destroy the Ion Cannon & the Shield Generators.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. The Rebel force consists of Luke in Speeder (becomes Luke on Foot if hit), Shield Generator, Ion Cannon, five Snow Speeders, two Laser Turrets, and six Rebel Troop Units. The Empire force consists of four AT-AT Walkers, two AT-AT Scouts, two Probe Droids, two Heavy Blaster Teams, and six Snow Troopers. Each unit is rated for movement distance and attack range. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move or attack.

“Battle between the Gungan & Federation Armies on Naboo. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe (Episode I). Each figure represents a Leader, Vehicle, or Unit of Troops. Victory: If the Shield Generator Beast is destroyed, the Robots win. The game ends automatically after you go through the deck twice when young Anakin destroys the Federation Carrier Ship, which shuts down all the Robots. The Gungan player wins at this time.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. The Gungan Units include Jar Jar Binks, Gungan Generals, Shieldmen, Slingers, Cavalry, Catapults, and a Shield Beast. The Federation Units include Hover Tanks, Battle Droids, and Droidekas. Each unit is rated for hit points, movement distance, and attack range. The players draw a hand of cards from a common custom deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

A two player boardgame based on the original Battlestar Galactica series, with one player as the Cylons and the other as the Battlestar Galactica.

The game is played on a single row of 100 squares. At one end is Caprica, the starting space for the Galactica, and at the other end is the lost colony of Earth. Every third square is a Planet space and the remaining squares are Deep Space.

The Cylon player is seeking to destroy all of the Galactica’s fighters. The Battlestar player wins if the Galactica makes it to Earth with some fighters left.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Big Trouble in Little China: Skirmish

item.description:
A board game based on the John Carpenter film Big Trouble in Little China.

“One player controls Egg Shen and his Allies. The other player controls Lo Pan & his Minions. Each figure represents one Man (Unit). Abstract simulation of the Battle at the end of the Movie. Victory: The Egg Shen player wins if he kills Lo Pan. Lo Pan wins if he kills Egg Shen, Jack Burton, and Wang Chi.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Egg Shen is teamed up with Jack Burton, Wang Chi, and six Chang Sing Fighters. Assisting Lo Pan are the Three Storms (Lightning, Rain, and Thunder), the Chinese Ogre, and eight Wing Kong Fighters.

The players draw hands of cards from a custom deck of 44 cards. Card play determines when units may move or attack.

“Card game. Simulates the Battle of Britain. July-September 1940. Players will have to make their own sets of cards.
The RAF and Luftwaffe have their own unique decks. Both decks have 62 cards. Notice that most cards have a force value. The Germans also need 20 tokens to represent bomb damage.”

Both players start the game with four cards. The players draw two cards at the start of each turn, with the maximum hand size at the end of the turn being eight cards. The German player has the option not to play a raid, in which case the turn ends. If the German player plays a raid, the players alternate playing force cards until neither player wants to play a card. The strength of the opposing forces are compared. If the RAF has a higher force total, the raid is stopped. If the German has the higher force total, then the amount of bombing damage caused by the raid is determined and added to the German’s score.

“If the German’s accumulate 20 points of bombing damage then they win. Hitler decides to go ahead with operation Sealion. If the German player goes to draw a card and there are no cards left in his deck the British win. Hitler postpones operation Sealion indefinitely.”

“Welcome to the World of the 25th Century. Help Buck defeat the Han Empire! The Decks: One player gets the Org Deck. The other player gets the Han Deck. Victory: The first player to win 5 hands is the winner.”

Each hand the players fill their hands to seven cards (Arrival Phase), can discard and redraw up to four (Reinforcements Phase), and then the players reveal some, none or all of their cards (Adventure Phase). Each player adds up the Force values of their cards, the player with the higher total wins the hand (Cliffhanger Phase.) The winner of the hand then makes an improvisational narrative of the Episode reflected by the turn using some or all of the cards played as a basis (Narrator Phase.)

A card game based on the characters and events from the movie The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the Eighth Dimension.

One player plays Team Banzai, the other player is the Red Lectroids. To win the game, be the first player to win eight hands, or win three hands in a row. A hand is won by the player who plays the meld having the highest Action Point total.

“Card game for 2+ players. Theme is the John Carter of Mars series by Edgar Rice Burroughs. Victory: The first player to accumulate 75 Victory Points (VP) wins. The Deck: Players share a common deck. There are several card types: Heroes, Villains, Beasts, Enemies, Weapons, Plots, Events. All cards fall into one of two categories: Friend cards or Foe cards. All cards have a numerical 'Force' value.”

The players attempt to form eight card melds consisting of at least one Hero or Heroine “Friend Card”, one Plot “Foe Card”, and at least one Enemy or Villain “Foe Card.” Because the good guys always win, the total Force value of the Friends Cards must equal or exceed the Force value of the Foe Cards. The player scores Victory Points equal to the Force value of the Foe Cards played in the meld.

“Board & card game for 2 players. World War Naval/Air II theme. Abstract Fleet & Squadron level combat. Each figure represents a group of Ships or Planes. Victory: You win if you destroy your opponent’s carriers.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units, which come in four types: Carriers, Warships, Subs, and Planes. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

A solitaire card game inspired by the Wolfenstein 3-D video game. The object of the game is to defeat the six bosses: Hans Grosse, Dr. Shabbs, Hitler Clone, Otto Giftmacher, Gretel Grosse, and General Fettgesicht. Along the way you will also face other Wolfenstein foes – Stormtroopers, Nazi Officers, Attack Dogs, and Zombies. Your hero starts with 20 hits. If you are reduced to zero or less hits, you lose.

A solitaire pencil and paper game which puts the player in the role of a Royal Air Force commander seeking to intercept attacking German aircraft during the Second World War.

“The game combines successful use of radar and RAF fighter resources to intercept German air fleets during the Summer of 1940.” The game is played with a six-sided die, a pencil, and the game sheet. The game lasts fifteen turns.

“Create your own tales of Conan the Barbarian and his adventures in Hyboria. All players share a single common deck. The deck contains six suits of cards: Conan cards, Locations, Events, Lesser Foes, Major Foes, & Specials. There are 30+ cards of each suit in the deck.”

The object of the game is to score the most victory points by playing melds from your six card hand. There are four types of melds that may be played: Three Pairs (two cards each from three suits), Two Three-of-a-Kinds (three cards each from two suits), Six-of-a-kind (six cards from one suit), or Flush (one card from each suit).

“Lord of the Rings Theme. Each player is their own 'Fellowship'. Victory: Players race to see who is the first to destroy the One Ring.”

The game is played on a track 72 spaces long. Designated spaces on the track represent the Shire, Moria, Mordor, Mount Doom, and other Middle Earth locations. Play Foe and Harship Cards on your opponents to hinder their progress. Use Aid Cards to defeat such cards played against you. To win the game, reach the last space on the game track and make a successful die roll to destroy the One Ring.

“Morocco circa 1925. Berber Tribesmen attack a company of French Foreign Legionnaires. Each player has a unique deck. Victory: The first player to win 4 hands wins the battle.”

Using eight card hands, the players each simultaneously play melds of Leader, Men, Terrain, Weapon, Morale and Tactics Cards. The player who plays the meld with the higher total Force Value wins the hand.

“Board & card game for 2 players. Highly abstracted skirmish level combat. Simulation of a counter-terrorist team operation. One side is the commandos: Delta/SAS/GSG-9/GIGN/etc. The other side is Terrorists holding hostages in a building. Victory: To win the Delta team must kill all the terrorists before taking 4 casualties. The Terrorists win if they kill 4 Delta team members, which allows them time to kill the hostages.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the commandos and terrorists. The terrorist group is composed of one Leader and seven Followers. The commando force consists of one Team Leader, three Shooters, two Demolitions Experts, and two Snipers. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

“The Special Forces have many more cards at their disposal, which reflects their high degree of training & experience.”

A card game based on the famous comic strip and movie detective. The game is played with a custom card deck composed of Crime Cards (Criminal, Felony, and Escape Cards) and Law Cards (Dick Tracy, Helper, Investigation, and Pursuit Cards.) The first player to solve three cases is the winner. To solve a case you have to form one of seven types of combos by taking turns drawing and discarding cards.

“Card game for 2 players. Based on the comic book character Doctor Strange. One player is the forces of good. The other player is the forces of evil. Victory: If, for 2 turns in a row, starting on turn 10, a player has no viable Characters in play, his opponent wins.”

A viable character is one of the player’s character cards that is not Killed, Incapacitated, Exiled, or Captured. Each viable character may make one attack each turn, resolved by die roll and card play. A successful attack can result in the attacker gaining control over one of the opposing player’s character. Characters may also be captured and rescued.

"The Deck: Players share a common deck. Card Types include: Characters, Companions, Locations, Items, Modifiers, Powers, Attacks, Events."

“Simulation of a Pistol Duel circa 1700+. Duelists agree to one of the following: One Shot, Multiple Shots (2,3,or 4), First Blood, Death. They may also forgo the Speed element of the Duel and allow the Challenged to fire first.”

The custom deck is divided into four suits: Speed, Aim, Range, and Hit. The Speed cards determine who fires first. Your Aim cards must total higher than your opponent’s Range cards to score a hit. The total of your Hit cards, when compared to those of your opponent, determine whether a player who was hit is wounded or killed.

Your success in the duel falls into one of four categories: “You are Killed: Major Defeat. You are Wounded: Minor Defeat. Opponent Wounded: Minor Victory. Opponent Killed: Major Victory.”

“Atredies vs Harkonnen for control of Dune. Each house starts with 5 Nobles. Victory: If you ever have 5+ more Spice Tokens than your opponent, you win. If you kill all opposing Nobles you win.”

The players attempt to gain control of Dune through card play. Each turn the player who controls Dune gains one Spice Token. House Atredies and House Harkonnen each have Special Abilities which provide die roll bonuses in various game phases.

“Solo card game. WWII Western Front. Player controls a squad of American GI’s on patrol. Fight German units.”

“The Decks: There are 2 separate decks: The GI Deck and the Patrol Deck. They have separate discard piles.”

“The Squad: Your squad has 15 soldiers. Use tokens to keep track of soldiers.”

“Victory: Get completely through the Patrol Deck. You lose if all of your squad members become casualties.”

“Solo card, dice & board game. Based on the Movie of the same name. Take on the role of Snake Plisskin.”

The game consists of seventeen scenes based on events and characters from the film. To aid in advancing through the scenes, a gameboard with a track of seventeen spaces can be drawn. The player gains cards at various stages. There are four different card types. Each type of card gives a bonus to a different type of die roll.

“Victory: Escape & Activate the Electro-Magnetic Pulse in the last Step. Losing: You lose if you ever get killed, or you do not get the antidote in 10 hours.”

Descriptions from the rules:

“Solo Dice Game. Simulation of an American solo F-14 Bombing Mission in the Middle East circa 1987. Pretty much like Microprose F-15 II. No realism, I think no Tomcat would do a solo bombing mission.”

“Mission: The mission consists 25 waypoints, first and last of which is home base. Draw the waypoints as circles connected with lines on a piece of paper. There are two targets in a mission, primary and secondary targets. First target is 2d6 waypoints from the 1st waypoint, the second 2d6 waypoints from the first target. Roll on the target table to determine what the targets are.”

“Scoring: Keep a running tally of points and kills while you play. You get awarded medals and promotions accordingly. You start with no medals and at a rank of 2nd Lt.”

Rules for a two-player cooperative variant are included.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
“Miniatures rules for aerial skirmishes. All combatants (Fliers) include a mount with usually one rider.”

The game features a diverse assortment of aerial combatants, all rated in two classes: Speed and Maneuverability. The Speed rating determines maximum speed, acceleration and deceleration rates, climb and dive rates, and modifiers for dodging and initiative. The Maneuverability rating determines turning rate, dodging ability, and initiative bonus. A wide variety of attack types are provided for: Spell, Poison, Ram, Grab, Petrification/Paralyze, Stun, Web/Net, Mesmerize, Fear, Smoke/Gas, and Fire/Acid Attacks.

With over fifty Mounts described in the game, Fantasy Fliers allows for just about every type of aerial combat you could think of – from bees, wasps, and butterflies to magic carpets, flying skulls, biplanes, and Pegasus.

“Card game for 2 players. WWI Aerial Dogfight Simulation. One player is the Germans, the other is the Allies. Victory: The first player to shoot down 4 enemy machines wins the battle. Use coins to keep track of ‘Kills.’”

The game is played using a custom card deck comprised of six suits made up of twelve cards numbered 1 to 12. These suits are Pilots, Allied Planes, German Planes, Tactics, Shooting, and Flying. All of the cards are usable by either player except for the Plane Cards - Allied Planes may only be used by the Allied player and German Planes may only be used by the German player.

Each turn the players are dealt hands of five cards. They may discard and redraw up to three cards. Each player then plays an Attack which must include a Pilot card and a Plane card. An attack may also include one card from each of the other three suits (Shooting, Tactics, and Flying.) A kill is scored when the total value of the cards played in an Attack is equal to or greater than the Attack played by the opposing player.

“WWI Biplane dog fighting. Get in your Sopwith Camel and take out some Albatrosses. 1 plane per player.” Statistics are provided for four aircraft: Sopwith Camel, Bristol F2b, Fokker D-VII, and Albatros C-V.

The game is played on a hex map. A custom deck of 52 cards is used to regulate combat and maneuvers. The Move Cards provide for left and right turns, hard turns, “slides”, and an Immelman loop.

Aircraft can shoot at any time during their movement by playing a Shoot Card. Aircraft with forward firing guns attack aircraft that are straight ahead, while those with a rearward firing observer can shoot at aircraft in a 60 degree arc of hexes to the rear of the plane. Damage is determined by a die roll modified based on range, which may result in 0 or less damage (indicating a miss).

A Critical Hits occurs when a 1 is rolled on the six-sided die rolled to determine damage. Critical Hits include the death of the observer or pilot, engine damage, critical structural or control damage, and fuel leakage.

The game also includes simple rules for altitude, ammunition, clouds, balloons, and ground fire (infantry, machine gunners, and flak.)

“Tactical Space Ship Combat Mayhem. Advanced Battleships.”

The game is played on a numbered hex grid. Miniatures or chits, marked for facing, are used to represent the spaceships. The players construct their own fleets based on lists of ships and weapon systems. The scenario sets the number of fleet points that each side starts with. Three scenarios are included in the rules.

Movement and combat are simultaneous, based on simple written orders. Combat occurs from the last space a unit enters. The written combat orders consist of indicating the weapon system fired and the mapsheet grid number being targeted. Damage inflicted depends on defensive equipment of the target ship (fields, screens and jammers) and the type of weapon used. Nukes and missiles caused fixed amounts of damage, while energy and projectile weapons have diminished capacity at longer ranges.

Statistics are given for nine types of base ships, ranging from the lowly Transport (used for scenario victory conditions) to the burly Battlestation. Ships are rated for cost, move, hits, number of shields, and number of weapons. Some types of ships can carry Fighter Squads. Ships can be equipped with three types of shields: Albedo Screens (protect against energy weapons), Intertia Fields (protect against projectile weapons), and Jammers (protect against missiles.) Weapon systems that can be purchased include Lasers, Rail Guns, Missile Launchers, Missiles, and Nuclear Missiles.

“Card & Dice game for 2+ players. Each player is a Gambler trying to win Big. Victory: The Winner is the first player to accumulate $5,000. If you ever lose all your money, you lose the game.” Each player starts with $5000. Pennies or other tokens are used as money, each being worth $100.

The game uses a custom set of cards. There are five types of cards in the deck: Casino Game Bets (Black Jack, Poker, Craps, & Roulette), Race Track Bets (Dogs, Horses, Jai Alai), Sports Bets (Baseball, Basketball, & Football), Win Cards and Special Cards.

Each turn a player plays a Bet card and rolls on a 2d6 Wager Table to determine the result. Win Cards can be played to modify the result. Multiple Casino and Sports bets may be made in one turn, but Casino and Track bets may not be made in the same turn. Special cards are played at the end of a player’s turn and add $100-$600 to a player’s bankroll as determined by a die roll.

The designer notes that the game is based on the gambling practices of his father and uncles.

“Card Game based on the RPG Gamma World by TSR. You are a leader of a Gamma World Enclave. Recruit and equip your followers. Send your followers to capture ruins that will aid your cause. Victory: The game ends when all cards have been drawn from the deck. The player controlling the most location cards wins.”

The game uses a custom card deck composed of the following types of cards: Weapons, Armor, Vehicles, Steeds, Equipment, Events, Mutations, Foes, and Locations.

Each turn a player receives a base allocation of two Action Points. Some cards will provide additional Action Points. Action Points are spent to perform the following actions: recruit one Follower, draw one card from the deck, play an Item card, or attack a Location.

link.value: From RPG books to board games

item.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between Jedi knights & Federation allies on Genosis. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe (Episode II). Each figure represents a Hero, Jedi, Creature or Unit of Troops. Victory: The game ends after you go through the deck twice when Yoda and the clone trooper gunships arrive. The player who has killed the most opposing units wins.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. There are ten Jedi units, twenty-two Federation units, and three Creature units.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend. The Creatures in the arena are not allied with the Jedi or Federation. Either player may cause Creatures to Move or Attack by playing Creature Cards.

“Players take turns changing the district lines in order to win the election.”

The game is played on a 10x10 grid. Each square represents a city block. At the start of the game, 100 Block Chits are randomly placed on the map. These Block Chits are randomly created by rolling for four characteristics: Income, Party, Race, and Issues.

Each player supports a candidate running for office. The candidate has eight profile characteristics: Income, Party, Race, two Allied Races, and three Issues ranked for priority.

There are four phases to the game. In the first phase, district lines are drawn by the players taking turns placing 1d6 District Markers on the map until all fifty District Markers have been placed. In the second phase, District Lines are redrawn – the players are able to move a randomly determined number of District Markers.

The third phase is the Census, in which the Block characteristics of the fifty blocks marked as part of the District are totaled. The fourth phase is the Election, in which the District votes for each candidate are calculated based on the Census data and the profile characteristics of the candidates.

The player whose candidate gets the most votes in the election wins the game.

“Board, dice, & card game for 2+ players. Wild West Theme. Battle between gunslingers. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill all enemy gunslingers.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Chits are used to indicate terrain features. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the gunslingers. There are seven types of gunslingers represented in the game: Cowboy, Outlaw, Indian, Lawman, Soldier, Pistol, and Rifle. Each type of gunslinger is rated for seven attributes, including Guts, Smarts, Cool, Eyes, and Hands.

The Action Deck is a custom deck of cards central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards for each gunslinger from this common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Optional rules are provided for horses, shotguns, and carrying multiple guns.

“G.I. Joe vs Cobra. 2 player game: Board, Cards, Dice. There are 2 decks. One player gets the Joe Deck. The other player gets the Cobra Deck. Victory: You win if you ever capture your opponent’s base, or you control all ‘Urban’ spaces on the board.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid with spaces large enough to hold a card. The G.I. Joe base is in one corner of the board and the Cobra base is in the opposite corner. The remaining 62 spaces are a random mix of eight terrain types: Jungle, Swamp, Sea, Desert, Mountain, Forest, Urban, and Arctic.

Each player starts with four Teams and a hand of cards. Each card has the name and statistics for a soldier. The cards are placed under each Team counter to represent the soldiers in that Team.

Teams engage in combat by moving into the same space as an opposing Team. Combat is resolved based on one of three unit factors (as determined randomly by a die roll): Firepower, Close Combat, or Tactics. Combat bonuses are given for various factors, including having a team with soldiers from the same service branch or when units are defending their base. Combat resolution also takes into consideration artillery units, armor units vs. anti-armor, and air units vs. “anti-air.”

A miniatures game based on the Mobile Suit Gundam universe.

The game includes statistics for over 50 different Mobile Suits from seven different Factions. In addition, the rules allow you to design your own Mobile Suits.

Eleven different generic Suit classes are defined, each of which is rated for Move Points, Hits, and Size Class (Small, Medium, and Large.) Seven classes of Weapons Systems are provided in the rules, with each being rated for Size, Damage, Range, Ammo, and Cost. The combat rules include hand-to-hand combat and critical hits.

“Players take the role of founding fathers of a medieval town. The best builder earns the title of Guild Master.”

The game is played with a custom deck of 116 cards. Each card specifies a type of Location and the Resources it provides. Some cards also specify additional Resources that are provided when they are combined with other specific Location cards.

Players obtain cards by drawing them from the deck and trading. On each turn, a player declares which type of Resource category to build, and then plays any cards of that category.

The game ends at the end of the turn that the last card is drawn from the deck. The winner is the player whose town provides the highest scores in the most number of Resource categories.

“Sci-Fi themed board & card game for 2 players. Each figure represents a vehicle, mech, or infantry squad. Victory: You rout the enemy if you destroy 9+ of his units.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each side starts with sixteen units: two Mechs, six Vehicles, and eight Infantry.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend. In addition, Obstacle cards may be played in response to movement cards, sometimes casuing the moving unit to sustain damage. Other special cards allow a unit to both move and attack in the same turn.

“Board & card game for 2 players. Napoleonic warfare theme. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a company or unit of men. Victory: You rout the enemy if you destroy 9+ of his units.”

The game is played on a chess board or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each side starts with sixteen units: eight Infantry, four Cavalry, and four Artillery. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

Optional rules provide for terrain, which comes in six types: Clear, Deep Water, Forest, Hill, Redoubt, and Marsh. The terrain features impact movement and combat in various ways.

“Board Game for 2 players. One player takes the role of the Hero Beowulf. The other player takes the role of the Monster Grendel. Victory: Slay your Foe. The first player to reduce his opponent to zero or less hits wins. Each player starts the game with 20 Hit Points.”

The game board is a track 13 spaces long. Each space on the board is a named location. These range from the Great Hall and other places favorable to the Danes at one end, to the dangerous swamps at the opposite end which favor Grendel.

Attack, Defense, and Ally Cards are used in combat. The other cards are used to perform various functions, such as assisting in travel or healing wounds. Some cards may be used to impede your opponent’s travel or to require your opponent to discard cards.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
